eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons.connectors

Class AgentConnector

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons.connectors.AgentConnector
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    RestAgentConnector

    public abstract class AgentConnector
extends java.lang.Object
    AgentConnector is the component of OGWAPI that represents an interface between the message oriented world of the OGWAPI and a protocol of your local infrastructure. This abstract class provides you with a set of methods that you need to override in your own implementation of AgentConnector. All of them will get executed when a respective request will arrive from some external object. It is recommended to create a separate package for your new AgentConnector in eu.bavenir.ogwapi.commons.connectors.{protocol} and put there classes that you need to support the connector. In contrast with CommunicationEngine there is only single instance of AgentConnector running for all the objects logged into the OGWAPI. This is a design decision taken early during the VICINITY project and any Agent implementation needs to make the final routing of incoming requests. Also keep in mind that your implementation needs therefore to be thread safe! Your AgentConnector implementation can serve multiple objects that are logged into your local instance of OGWAPI. An AgentConnector implementation should always return NetworkMessageResponse. See its definition to get more information about how it works, however for quick understanding here are all the methods you need to get started: 1. Create a new NetworkMessageResponse. 2. Use setError to indicate whether an error happened during execution. 3. Set a response code with setResponseCode and a response code reason with setResponseCodeReason. Consult the CodesAndReasons and Error propagation chapter in the OGWAPI documentation to get a clue on values to be set. 4. Set the content type of the response with setContentType. Use of HTTP compliant content types is encouraged, but using any other string should not cause a crash. 5. Finally set response body with setResponseBody and return it. It is highly recommended to read Error propagation chapter in the OGWAPI documentation to see how the error gets propagated across the network. Also a peek into CodesAndReasons can give you some insight about valid error codes and the reasons for them. In the reference implementation of the RestAgentConnector you'll find out that the code and reason that gets transported to the other side of the network will usually be taken directly from the REST client that communicates with your local infrastructure. As it was the first implementation of the OGWAPI ever (as of 2018) it is likely that the content of the CodesAndReasons will remain similarly HTTP oriented in the near future. Setting the values other way than directly grabbing them from the REST client is demonstrated in the performDummyOperation of the RestAgentConnector.
    Author:
    sulfo

    • Method Detail

      • forwardEventToObject

        public abstract NetworkMessageResponse forwardEventToObject(java.lang.String sourceOid,
                                                            java.lang.String destinationOid,
                                                            java.lang.String eventId,
                                                            java.lang.String body,
                                                            java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parameters)
        This method gets executed when an event belonging to local object ID is received and needs to be forwarded to its respective device.
        Parameters:
        sourceOid - The object ID that published the event.
        destinationOid - Subscriber object ID.
        eventId - ID of the event channel.
        body - Body of the event.
        parameters - Any parameters that were inserted into the event.
        Returns:
        Response. See the main documentation for this class on how to create and fill the object.
